messageBody:
Robert Scheffel wrote:

> I'm assigned the task of using JUnit to test the Java implementation of Use
> Cases. Typically, a Use Case is implemented across several objects,
working
> together to accomplish a task. This is one level out from unit testing one
> object; this is testing the integration of more than one object.
>
> Does JUnit facilitate and support the integration testing of multiple
> components?

Short answer: Sure, a JUnit test can call more than one method in sequence,
to act sort of as a controller for a use case, and/or call a method on a
controller that runs the use case, and then test to make sure the use case
exhibited the desired behavior (some behaviors, like the generation of web
pages may need some additional tools like HTTPUnit).

A few of us on our team have been discussing different flavors of "unit"
testing over the past few days...

From the outside in, there are tests that operate on the outermost surface
area of the system, treating the whole thing as much of a black box as
possible. In other words, they generate the same stimuli as the users, and
test for the same behaviors that the user would expect. The sequence of
stimuli and behaviors is essentially a scenario of a use case. I believe
these are typically called acceptance tests.

Once we start peeking under the hood, we can go after parts of the system -
subsystems and collaborations of objects - and test them for functional
behavior as well. A use case scenario gets decomposed into more detailed
internal scenarios that assign responsibility for the use case behaviors to
objects and collaborations. This decomposition/scenario design is a more
formal process step in some methodologies, and is less formal in XP but
something a good designer will consider nevertheless. We can write tests
that run the internal scenario, generating the stimuli (probably method
calls) and looking for the correct behavior (state changes, generated
outputs, etc.). I don't know what to call these - perhaps "functional
unit tests." These seem to be more of what you're talking about.

[BTW, has anyone found that these kinds of test can be a real pain,
especially if the scenario represents behavior somewhere "in the middle"
of a longer-running use case? The set up can get complicated to make
sure the system state is correct to start the test, and/or the tear down
can get complex to make sure we leave the system in a good state. I've
seen suggestions to use mock objects that behave as if the system state
is correct to get around some of this. Comments?]

Then there's another type of test. If we take an object (class), and its
collection of methods, we can write tests that exercise each method. If
we want complete coverage, we write tests that exercise all the code paths
of each method, test for ranges of parameter values, etc. These tests
aren't concerned with how the object works in a collaboration, just with
how the object works in relative isolation. I consider these "unit tests"
but that's just my opinion. Note that as we look at objects that represent
collaborations of objects (e.g., controllers, facades, etc.), their methods
may trigger or control an internal scenario, hence a unit test for them
starts to take on the flavor of the "functional unit tests" above.

As far as what tools you use to run the tests, it can be JUnit or another
testing tool ranging from hand built code to big testing tools like Segue
Silk Test or some such. JUnit is very good at writing tests that call
Java methods and look for behavior that can be tested by calling Java
methods. Tests that need to generate, for example, HTML posts and look
at generated HTML output, may be better written with HTTPUnit or Silk
Test, etc. Tests that work against databases may need SQLUnit, etc.

Just for the record, I'm not at all claiming that anything written above
is part of XP. These are just some of our recent musings on unit testing,
and we're probably over-analyzing things, but that keeps us off the
streets. ;-) Your post related to them, and it seemed as good a time as
any to toss them out and see what happens.

A question for the list: How do you organize your tests, particularly
if you write tests that are of both the functional scenario and single
object unit test varieties? The common approach seems to be to gather
all the tests for a given class in one test class. What about the
scenario type of tests? Organized by use case? What communicates
better, especially if we want to use the tests as documentation?

Regards,
-Paul
